awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Demographic Impacts of State-Sponsored Medical Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
Even though knowledge about the bio-cultural conditions of infertility has changed dramatically since the invention of in vitro fertilization (IVF), the most effective infertility treatment today, experiences with reproductive technologies can vary significantly. Assisted reproductive technologies (ARTs) such as IVF can be heavily leveraged and regulated by governments with protonalist policy objectives; and depending on who avails themselves of these reproductive technologies, those policies can have significant demographic impacts. This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous empirically-grounded scientific fieldwork, explores what social, cultural, and demographic changes result from the use of state-sponsored medical technologies by ethnic minorities faced with social pressure reproduce.  

Safak Kilictepe, under the supervision of Dr. Sarah Phillips of Indiana University will conduct research on the relationship between IVF and ethnic-minority status. The research is situated in a context that allows the researcher to investigate how infertile ethnic minority women living in socio-politically changing environments experience their infertility. The researcher will explore how ethnic minority women, who live in societies in which women's socioeconomic status significantly depends on their fertility, respond to and make use of government regulated IVF technology to achieve their own reproductive interests and validate their own gendered identities as women and mothers. The research will take place in Turkey, one of the world's fastest growing and tightly regulated IVF markets. The researcher will conduct twelve months of ethnographic research in the capital city (four months) and a southeastern city (eight months) dominated by a Kurdish minority population in Turkey. The methods include participant observation, interviews (with 108 individuals), and textual and statistical data analysis. Findings will be disseminated to guide policy makers, practitioners, and scholars developing education materials for, and/or making policies about reproduction and reproductive technologies.

por.por_cntn:
This dissertation research project has provided data for understanding of how the relationship between in vitro fertilization (IVF), political Islam, and changing ethnic-minority status shapes the reproductive experiences and negotiations of infertile Sunni Kurdish women in Turkey. Reproductive technologies, for this project, provide lens to answer the following questions: 1) How do ethnic minority women - experiencing shifting politics and living in societies in which women's socioeconomic status significantly depends on their fertility- respond to and make use of government-regulated IVF technology to achieve their own reproductive interests and validate their own gendered identities as women and mothers? 2) In what ways reproductive regulations affect the demographic structure at the local level? 3) How does the concept of race intersect with the definitions of gender, religion, ethnicity, and nation; and how does this, in turn, shape the experiences of individuals belonging to different groups regarding their reproduction?

Reproductive policies and marketing strategies might further jeopardize minority women’s well-being, and violate both their basic human rights and reproductive rights since they are already in vulnerable positions. Thus, it is crucial to identify to how reproductive technologies are promoted, regulated and practiced to understand how they affect minority women’s bodies, lives, and demographics of the nation. This study sheds light on how minority women participate in the use of regulated reproductive technologies not from a stand point of “false-consciousness” thesis, but with an attempt of grasping their “own interests and agendas” by taking part in the state’s political and economic agendas. The research adds to humanistic knowledge of reproduction by showing how choices and constrains of women living in the midst of shifting politics are interlaced. Understanding myriad forms of reproductive interests and its demographic outcomes—all of which are shaped historically and socio-politically—will guide policy makers, politicians, women’s rights activists and scholars to consider diverse women’s reproductive needs when advocating for, providing education materials, and/or making policies about reproduction and reproductive technologies.

Feminist science and technology studies focusing on Turkey have come to the fore in recent years, especially with the rise of the national and international usage of IVF technology in Turkey (Goknar, 2015; Gürtin & Inhorn, 2011; Gürtin-Broadbent, 2013; B. Mutlu, 2017). The question of how politicized ethnic groups living in the politically shifting environment experience IVF and regulations with IVF at the individual, societal, and national level, however, has remained unanswered. Although there has been a substantial body of literature on the demographics of Turkey, it still remains distant from the question of how reproductive interventions and technological developments shape the demographic outcomes (meanings of gender, family, ethnicity and nation) of a society at the local level. Though critical approaches have advanced our understandings of how demography is shaped by different power dynamics and global relations, the existing literature is heavily focused on Western societies (Ginsburg & Rapp, 1995; Greenhalgh, 1995). It is important to develop tools to conceptualize demography in non-Western contexts due to their different historical background (Rivkin-Fish, 2003). This project provides methodological and intellectual approaches to understand demographical structure in a non-Western context. For example, it specifically answers to the questions of how might the civil marriage condition in the use of reproductive technologies change the demographic pattern of a society that historically prioritizes religious marriage and commonly practices polygamy? What happens to co-wives who do not have civil marriage when they are dealing with infertility? Further, how might the age limit imposed on the use of reproductive technologies affect women who do not fit into this category, and whose identification cards might not reflect their real age because of sociopolitical reasons? Many women who I met in Diyarbak?r told me that their age is either randomly assigned by their father or the state officials, or is changed with their younger brothers’ age to delay the brothers’ compulsory military service. Doctors at the state hospital refused many women who came to the state hospital for infertility treatment because either these women did not have licensed marriage (since they had religious marriage and/or were the second/third wives), or due to their age. Most of them came back to the clinic after getting their licensed marriages, but others could not since they cannot have licensed marriage as second/third wives. I argue that national reproductive interventions create demographic frictions at the local level, which, in turn, reshapes the meanings of gender and family. Furthermore, I discuss that different demographic frictions emerge as a result of the government’s regulations due to different historical and political trajectories at the local level. Demographic interventions might create layered effects on different individuals depending on how close their citizenship category is to the criteria of the state’s.
